descriptions.title: An Overview of Tibetan Dialects
descriptions.content:
This map of Tibetan dialects represents the work of Nicolas Tournadre. The top-level categories are dialect groups, which do not correspond to any specific individual spoken languages as such. The basic criteria for identifying one set of spoken Tibetan dialects as a different dialect group than another set of spoken Tibetan dialects is the mutual intelligibility test. Given the difference in phonology, vocabulary, and grammar between these two sets of spoken Tibetan, when a native speaker of a dialect from one group meets a speaker of a dialect from the other group, can the two speakers immediately make a serious attempt at a conversation in that initial meeting, even if they struggle quite a bit? If not, then they are different dialect groups; if so, then they are in fact one dialect group. Across dialect groups, the lack of mutual comprehension is pretty much at the level of, for example, a German speaker meeting an English speaker and trying to have a meaningful conversation.

It is important to realize that prior to modern times with their tremendous linguistic standardization deriving from new media, mass literacy, and other issues, even in European counties like France or Italy, the spoken dialects existed in dialectic groups across which there was no comprehension. Within dialectic groups, it can be useful in some cases to further analytically discern subgroups, and more rarely, even analyze subgroups into further subdivisions. All of these means of classification are artificial constructs based upon shared linguistic affinities between actual spoken forms of the language. These dialect group classifications do not correspond to any specific spoken form of the language that is practiced by a specific community of individuals.

The actual spoken form of language then is called a “dialect.” Here we enter the reality of actual language spoken by individuals in communities. In a very general geographical way, you might think of a dialect corresponding to speakers in a single contemporary “county” (rdzong).
